Well, this idea didn't pan out. While the game itself is unchanged(which was orginally pretty good) the idea doesn't really work. This game was built as a top down game not a 3rd person shooter, and it's apperent in the game.

Aiming doesn't work in 3rd person like it does in top down. Using a bow and arrow is almost impossible. Each shot actually shoots one or two feet away from it's intened location when aiming at moving targets. Now I understand that if I was moving then there'd be a change, but if I'm standing still the arrow should go where I aim it(or atleast close to it). The thing that gets me is that it works perfectly fine on stationary targets. I aim at the head and the arrow goes into the head(even if the zombie is moving up and down while eating something on the ground), but once they start moving you better pull out your melee cause there's no telling where the shot will go. I shouldn't have to compensate for a target  moving directly at me.

The animations also feel off. Again, the game was made top down not as 3rd person so that explains it, It doesn't excuse it, but explains it.

Overall the game feels like an Alpha. It needs some more polish before I think about starting it up again.

I needed to write this review because too many people don't know how to play it - unfortunately, these people are mostly those who tried the other version of the same game. Personally, I feel this is WAY better than the top down mode.

Now, for those who are still confused on aiming... Do NOT try to lead anything. Not ever. Even if they are 100 yards away, you time your click so that it is RIGHT when their head (or whatever you want to hit) is on the dot. Even if the arrow looks like it will miss, it won't, and you will get head shots every time provided you can aim. This is directly due to the fact that this game was originally a different perspective, so impact prediction is not the same as a game in which this was planned. Just remember what I've told you and you'll see it is no problem.

This was honestly one of the best surprises for a game I've already owned that I've had in a very long time. Very much worth it!

reviewText:
As a fan of the original, I was pretty excited about this itteration of the original How To Survive. After about 45 minutes in... well, you know how some develpoers take a mobile game and just slap it on PC with little to no change? This is kind of the same idea, except it was a top-down shooter turned into a 3rd person shooter. It shows bad.

The original was a top down shooter, thus all the derpy melee animations were forgiveable and controls worked as it was. This is basically a move of the camera with a few control tweaks. Aiming is attrocious, so don't even bother trying to use anything ranged for headshots, so that's half of the weapons are a pain to use. In the original, it'd lock on to headshots after aiming at an enemy for a while. Now, in addition to the fact that to hit anything, you have to aim somewhere to the right of everything, but since most zombies hobble back and forth so quick, headshots are a pain, unless they're unaware you're there.

Also, now you have to tote around flint all the time to light fires. In the original, you lit them as soon as you got your first skill and they stayed lit. Now, not only do you need flint to light them as a consumable, but the rain will put them out. I'm not sure if I like this or not... yet... I haven't played this enough to decide. I CAN tell you I don't like the fact that the inventory, skills, etc screen doesn't pause the game, as it takes several clicks to combine things or use something. While this is happening, a zombie can easily get a cheap hit in, especially at night with the crawly ones. (Which to keep away witht he flashlight, you need to walk in an occasional circle to keep them back, both in the original and this one.)

The game could really use a mini-map or compass. Since the original was top-down, it's easy to tell north from south, but now to decern which way you're facing, but here you have to check the map. A small gripe, but it's tedious.


Anyways, I hope the devs plan on putting some effort into a patch, now that I can't get a refund because it's passed 14 days. (Forgot I had it pre-ordered and got busy.) I would've gotten a refund right away and hoped they did better later, but hey... they got my money. Can't do anything about it but wait now. It's a shame, because I like how the new persective looks and I liked the first itteration just fine.

reviewText:
Taken as a standalone game it's fun if a bit challenging. Once you learn the controls and how to aim you can venture through the islands without too much trouble. Being able to see off into the distance and sniping zombie hordes before they get to you makes things a lot easier. The story, setting, crafting and missions are all solid and entertaining.  As far as individual games go I am having fun with it and would recommend it.

But.

As far as sequels, remakes or what ever this would be called this falls short in comparison to the original. This is the original game from a different camera perspective. The story, island layout, quests, crafting and generally everything in this game is exactly the same as the original more or less. This shows through as you progress through the game. The maps, area layout, enemy AI and spawning seem to be the same as they were in the original. Unfortunately the original was a top down camera angle game so those elements were designed with having a 360 view around your character. Without that perspective you can easily find yourself swarmed at times with nowhere to run. If you played the original and were a fan of the top down version do not go into this expecting the same experience. The game play is fairly different with a greater need for spacial awareness of your surroundings and where you are.

So to summarize

As it's own game it's entertaining and I recommend it. If you were a fan of the original go in with an open mind and be ready to learn new tactics.

reviewText:
At first, this looks like a good idea: take a good Top-down Hack-em-up and make it Third (almost First) person and it should be good, right?

No. Not at all. This game does not translate well to a 3d-perspective. Playability is dismal and leaves one wondering what is wrong with their keyboard. Targeting and striking is not precise and requires a fair amount of guesswork. You almost get the enjoyment of playing a game while being drunk, but without being intoxicated at all; it's the game, not you. The remainder of the game feels like a shadown of How to Survive or rather a beta test that needs work.

BUT... that's not really the problem with this putrid game.

Do you like Lagzilla? Do you? I don't. I could understand frame-rate issues if the details are set high and the PC is not up to it. However, a significant delay between pressing a key or button (1/2 second or more) is simply inexcusable. It is not limited to movement or attacks either, this wonderous feature also applies to mouse movement, rotating the camera, and even, as an added bonus, navigating the menu! Want to exit the game and be done with it? Well, be prepared to fight the interface to be free!

One of the charming aspects of this games 2d predecessor is the witty animations and narrations, subtly echoing the inane deliruim of the Pip-man character from the Fallout series. While these ran perfectly fine in that title, they don't here. Instead, we partake in a garbled mess of interlaced vomit smeared across the screen. If you think changing settings will fix this, think again. Perhaps you're the ingenious sort who fiddles with his computer and updates video codecs with great skill and precision. Well, fooled you twice, no dice for you! Perhaps you can just watch the original videos on some Youtube Lets Plays and fast-forward to the needed footage. It's not like you paid for this game or anything.

It's sad, really. The publishers did fair job on this games predecessor, How to Survive: Storm Warning Edition. It wasn't perfect, it wasn't even a 8/10 title, but it was acceptable, fun, and (most importantly) FUNCTIONAL. In this version, while we get to get a annoyed-parrot's eye view of the action, the daunting task of making the game work properly was clearly not a priority. In fact, it wasn't even on the list... not even the To-Do-When-Everything-Else-Is-Done List.

It dissapoints me to pay money for a game and find that the publisher has taken an Up yours" attitude towards its customers. The development clearly went straight from alpha directly to publication. There is no excuse for this rubbish.

Do not buy this game. Look at the screenshots

reviewText:
TLDR at bottom.

This version takes every problem from the first game and amplifies them to stupifying proportions. It still has a lack of direction throughout, combined with a awkward crafting system. Now the fact that items never had an object glow and most of them blended in with the rest of the game is strikingly apparant in third person. Finding things isn't hard, but only if you have played the game previously. This game is, for many reasons, a extremely bad way to make a game for newcomers. It is too heavily inaccessible for new players, too clunky/janky, and the lack of direction will just confuse and turn off all new players. I hadn't played the game in forever so I forgot to pick up a piece of flint on the beach to light a fire. The game does not tell you to do that so I went to the forum and of course right there on the first page someone else had posted about it and I had to use that information just to learn to pick up a piece of flint to start a fire. Probably the stupidest problem yet though is the way night time affects you now in third person. I will just list below the lame-brained ♥♥♥♥ I can think of as I go.

- In third person you get to see how laughably bad the graphics, animations, hitboxes on enemies, hitboxes when firing ranged weapons, and combat are. Zooming this game in was a bad idea. The top down version is far, far superior to this, but still not a very good game anyway.
- Combat was doable in the top down version because of things like a reticule over the enemies head when you hover the mouse over them and as it got smaller, homed in so you could get a headshot, alowing you to get a few headshots before you got rushed and had to switch to melee. Now, that is gone, and ranged combat just feels horribly awkward.
- With the top down version, you could see all around you and in the dark when the night creatures came up behind you, you could turn around and shine your flashlight on them. Now of course because it is in third person, you can't see behind you so those night creatures can now just casually come right up behind you before you have any clue and dmg you.
- It still has items that seemingly never combine with anything else and are useless (white herbs, blue herbs, etc)
- Zombies can still do a awkward circle-slide move around you, which I have seen in many sloppily coded zombie games, making you take unavoidable dmg while dancing with them.
- Healing herbs are, like they were in the first version of the game, incredibly rare until later in the game. That was tolerable then, but now with new problems I'm going to list next that make you take dmg way more often in third person view, it is a bad problem.
- Guns: Forget about firing a weapon at zombies if they are anywhere near you. The hit detection is so bad that when a zombie is near me and I fire the shotgun, it just misses while the zombie has a awkward movement to my left-front side and does dmg to me. If I want to hit it now, I have to aim at a wierd straight-down-left-of-center angle because firing directly into it while it's close feels like the bullets are just clipping through it, because they are.
- Bow: same goes for the bow. As the enemies get closer to you, even if you are aiming directly into them, arrows miss. The only way to really kill anything is with melee. It wasn't like that in the reg version. Aiming was good and even had a reticule that would power up while on a enemy's head allowing you to get headshots occasionally. Now, you are required to use free aim.
- Free aim is a mess because of slightly unresponsive mouse movement. Your view does not snap instantly with your mouse movement, it takes a fraction of a second to catch up and feels like mouse lag. I saw other people post about it in the forums as well. It feels uncomfortable to say the least.
- When you are low on health you walk very, very slow, basically drag your feet, and since there are no healing herbs early on, this is a big problem. Unless of course you like traversing a game at 1mph.
- I could go on, but this is long enough already.

TLDR: Like I said, rather than introduce a fun new way to play, the third person view just zooms in on the already existing problems, magnifying them into worse and even new issues. A third person survival game that comes to mind in comparison (albeit without zombies) is Tomb Raider, which is infinitely better than this in every possible aspect. If you want a real zombie survival third person game that is actually done well and feels like a real game and not a janky awkward bad-hitbox mess with lack of direction and a poorly executed crafting system like this game, State of Decay is a very good game, far exceeding this game in every aspect you could possibly think of.

Like i gave the top down version, thumbs down. That I gave a 5/10, so to be fair this would be a 4/10 at best. I paid $3 for this, and that was $3 too much.

reviewText:
So I have played this and the original game. What  I like about this game so far. The view looks good and makes it feel more alive rather then the over head view. It comes with almost all the DLC of the original game. I did not own any DLC of the original game. The game does look more alive thanks to the 3rd person viewpoint however that also shows the ugly side of the graphics that were sort of hidden by the older view point. The enemies you have to kill are slighty  Fugly.  The textures just dont have a lot of pop to them.

The fighting is mostly good. Getting a critical hit on a zombie is a good feeling. The bad feelins is trying to figure out when to press the A button for an insta kill on a zombie. It  feels  very finiky and sometimes comes up and sometimes never comes up. Its annoying. This is for melee weapons only. The aiming for both melee and ranged weapons is  a mixed bag. The bow felt weird to fire. I missed a lot of easy shots for whatever reason. Just to add some more thoughts on combat. When they changed the view point they should have changed the way to aim a lot more then they did. Arrows and throwing bombs felt very off and often I would miss an easy throw with a bomb thanks to no guide on where it would land. Annoying.

I would say if you didnt like the first game your probably not going to like this game. I should mention one big thing that is sure to annoy some people. The game has no multiplayer. The original game did have co op. This one does not. I do not mind this but some may. I think if you enjoyed the first one then you may like this one as well. Just depends if you like the 3rd person view point or not. I think for the low price of $3 dollars for originial owners is a nice deal.  I think the higher price for people who do not own this game could be a mixed bag. After playing this a lot more I am more inclined to say that people who have never played this are going to have a MUCH harder time enjoying this game. To me its a lot harder even on the easy mode. Easy mode to me feels like hard mode. Not to mention the bug with the stick you carry it breaks on the very first mission. That to me is a very big bug in the gameplay.

reviewText:
How to Survive is your quintessential zombie slaughter and escape style of game.  The game takes place on a tropical island upon where you wake up on the beach surrounded by 'zombies' of various makes and models.  You must then fight your way through the undead and the elements by crafting, looting and clearing.  The idea holds up pretty well, even in the dirge of zombie-themed survival games simply because this one has more of an action-adventure feel.  It's fast paced, gives you plenty to shoot at and crafting is simple and intuitive.

The survival mechanics are pretty basic: drink water, eat food and get some sleep/caffine each day.  There's not much to it and it's pretty forgiving so I'm not sure it really adds much to the adventure, but at the same time it doesn't detract from it either.  The crafting, on the other hand, is actually done quite well.  Instead of a 'gather materials/find bench' approach, you actually combine parts into the finished product.  I really like this approach.  You don't put items in a grid or follow a recipe, you simply combine parts until you get a finished product.  The order you do so is usually pretty lax too, so it serves as both an intuitive interface but also as clever inventory management as most things can be broken down again.  Since you are limited to combinations the game accepts, it's perhaps a bit limiting since that serves as your guidance for doing so, but I found it more interesting than the typical crafting offered by other games.

The game itself is a 'update' from a top down twin stick shooter, and personally I think both versions work alright, though the world itself was clearly built from an overhead perspective so there is a conspicous lack of things such as indoor areas.  Additionally there is a clear distinction between 'paths' and 'walls' and the perspective does make the island feel a lot smaller.  However, the translation to 3rd person works.  The biggest issue I ran into is simply trying to shoot an enemy very close to me.  You'll absolutely want to switch to your melee weapons in these types of scenarios as the game does not have any aim assist, shoulder swapping or range compensation.  It's a small hiccup though, I found it to be just as or even more enjoyable than the original.

The debate on whether it should be it's own product or a standalone aside,  I think this game has gotten a far worse rap than it deserves, it's functionally and technically sound.  It's recognizable among the endless hordes of similar titles thanks to some off-beat humor and despite being mindless fun, has quite a bit of content and challenge if you are up for the harder modes.  If you are looking for a decent single player zombie survival experience with an action adventure feel, here you go: it's cheap, fun and not in early access.
